metadata.case_name: Appellant (Employee/Inspector) v. Bharat Nidhi Ltd. (formerly Bharat Bank Ltd.)

facts.text: Appellant took up service with respondent (then Bharat Bank Ltd.) from July 1, 1944, as Inspector at Bombay in grade Rs. 170-10-200-20-400.
Appellant given three increments, first from October 1, 1945.
Promotions on October 1, 1946, and October 1, 1947; drawing Rs. 240 per month plus Rs. 30 special allowance.
Appellant discharged by respondent on August 5, 1949, as surplus to requirements.
Government referred disputes to Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Calcutta, by Notification dated February 21, 1950.
Tribunal held on December 5, 1950, discharge illegal; directed reinstatement and arrears of salary/allowances within one month of publication (Gazette December 30, 1950).
Respondent appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal on January 30, 1951; appeal dismissed September 25, 1951.
Appellant wrote to respondent on October 10, 1951, offering to report for duty at Bombay and claiming arrears.
Appellant served notice through solicitors on November 5, 1951, claiming Rs. 32,388 as compensation for non-reinstatement.
Government replied on May 13, 1952, to appellant's application under s.20(1), advising revised application for arrears and s.20(2) for computation.

Respondent (now Bharat Nidhi Ltd.) transferred business to Punjab National Bank Ltd., closed branches; letter April 3, 1952, giving two months' notice under s.19(6) Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, claiming appellant surplus.
Appellant replied April 16, 1952, via advocates, noting no response to prior letter.
Respondent letter May 10, 1952, claiming appellant failed to join at Delhi office, treating as absence.
Respondent letter June 28, 1952, to Government, stating arrears paid, appellant failed to resume duty.
Appellant filed petition under s.20(2) on October 8, 1952, claiming Rs.47,738.
Respondent written statement December 4, 1952: appellant violated instructions, forfeited rights; award terminated under s.19(3).
Industrial Tribunal awarded Rs.1,000 under s.20(2) on January 24, 1953, using s.95 CPC analogy.
Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed on April 29, 1954, dismissing appeal as incompetent.
Appellant obtained special leave; appeal to Supreme Court.
Tribunal found respondent guilty of unfair labour practice and victimization in 1950 award.
Bye-laws: Resignation/termination on one month's notice or pay in lieu; retirement at 55.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondent refused to implement reinstatement award or appellant failed to resume duty.
Computation in terms of money of the benefit of reinstatement under s.20(2) of Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950.
Competency of appeal to Labour Appellate Tribunal under s.7 of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent failed to reinstate despite directions; entitled to full compensation till superannuation (55 years, May 4, 1960) including salary, PF, gratuity.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.20(2) Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950

petitioner_arguments.text: Computation on basis of full tenure, breach of contract, or tort with special damages.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Contract law principles; Chitty on Contracts

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant failed to report for duty at Delhi despite instructions; forfeited reinstatement rights.
Award terminated after one year under s.19(3) Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; business transferred, surplus.
Appeal incompetent under s.7 Act; no substantial question of law.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.7 Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950

respondent_arguments.text: Impossible to reinstate due to transfer to Punjab National Bank; only few employees absorbed.

court_reasoning.text: Findings on facts in favour of appellant: ready and willing to join, no default; respondent did not plead impossibility earlier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Correspondence shows respondent insisted on joining at Delhi, never claimed impossibility till evidence stage.

court_reasoning.text: s.20(2) computation not damages for breach but value of reinstatement benefit from award date, considering tenure, notice, retirement age, possibilities of termination, etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not analogous to wrongful dismissal damages or s.95 CPC; reinstatement continues original contract terms.

court_reasoning.text: Bye-laws allow termination on one month's pay; but unfair practice finding limits this; estimate Rs.12,500 reasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Balance probabilities pro and con; present value till superannuation.

holdings.text: Appellant not in default; entitled to computation of reinstatement benefit.
Money value under s.20(2) is estimate of reinstatement benefit value, not contract breach damages; Rs.12,500 awarded.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collier v. Sunday Referee Publishing Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Damages for fixed-term contract measured by lost salary subject to mitigation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Salt v. Power Plant Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Damages assessment considers possibilities like company winding up, termination, life expectancy.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Recovery of money due; computation of non-monetary benefits; appeal competency.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Rejected analogy for compensation on insufficient grounds for arrest etc.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Labour Appellate Tribunal decision and Industrial Tribunal award set aside; appellant awarded Rs.12,500 as computation of reinstatement benefit value.

key_quotes.text: The monetary value of the benefits of such reinstatement is therefore to be computed not on the basis of a breach of the contract of employment nor on the basis of a tort alleged to have been committed by the employer.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We have come to the conclusion that having regard to all the circumstances of the case it would be reasonable to compute the benefit of reinstatement which was awarded to the appellant at an amount of Rs. 12,500.
key_quotes.speaker: court
